document.docAuthor: Motamedinia, Behnam, Skevington, Jeffrey H. & Kelso, Scott
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of Tomosvaryella Aczél (Diptera: Pipunculidae) in the Middle East, with description of 19 new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of Tomosvaryella Aczél (Diptera: Pipunculidae) in the Middle East, with description of 19 new species

bibRefCitation.author: De Meyer, M.
bibRefCitation.refString: De Meyer, M. (1995) The pipunculid flies of Israel and the Sinai (Insecta, Diptera, Pipunculidae). Spixiana, 18, 283 - 319.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis: This species can be recognized by a small projection in hind trochanter (Fig. 47C); epandrium wider than long in dorsal view ( Fig. 26A ); syntergosternite 8 slightly rounded in dorsal view ( Fig. 26A ); ejaculatory ducts coiled ( Fig. 26C–D ); gonopods equal in height ( Fig. 26B ); hypandrium slightly rounded, wider than gonopods in ventral view ( Fig. 26B ). Based on the shape of surstyli in dorsal and lateral view, this species resembles
T. pruinosa Kozánek, 1992
.
Tomosvaryella pruinosa
lacks the small projection in hind trochanter. In addition, there is a gap between the surstyli and cerci of
T. nodosa
in lateral view ( Fig. 26C–D ). Meanwhile, It is similar to
T. hamounensis
sp. nov .
See the diagnosis notes under
T. hamounensis
sp. nov .
for more details.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 26. Male genitalia of
Tomosvaryella nodosa
(CNC470508, CNC) A) dorsal view, B) ventral view, C, D) lateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution: Egypt , Iran , Israel , United Arab Emirates ( Skevington 2020 ) ( Fig. 59 ).

Note: Based on DNA barcodes,
T. nodosa
is similar to
T. pruinosa
, differing by 4.2%. (pairwise divergence) (Supplementary Table 1 ).
